Test yourself. Do you know everything you need to know? With this super fun quiz you will practice all the courses you get in your group. 600 questions alternating questions and answers. With explanations and illustrations. For each group - from 3 to 8 - has its own quiz.

Topics: language - count - History - Society - Geography - Earth, space and environment - physics and technology - nature - traffic - English

The questions are on the left flaps, the answers on the right flaps. Turn the right flap to the answer.

Who answers correctly get a point. Winner is the player with the most point.

name: Lumpi Waldi Struppi
description:
Objective: gain as little as possible sacrificing points
- acting by turns - each player starts with 5 - two-player game, alternative 4 - (coloured) meeples, on top a white (=happy), below a black (=sad) dog; move according die roll (forward or backward); ending on a white space a meeple may be kicked by another one (back to start) and flipped to 'sad' dog. A 'flower' space is safe. Game ends after one player moved all own meeples into target zone (field 25). Depending on position and status (happy/sad) penalty points are assigned to each player. remarks: published ~ 1940

name: Het Lettergrepenspel
description:
In this card-game you lay down your cards to create words like in scrabble but there are syllables instead of letters on the cards.
Also, like scrabble you can add your cards to existing cards making words horizontal and vertical. Each card has a value and adding the values of your cards gives your score.

name: Superboy
description:
"Can Superboy Escape The Deadly Green Kryptonite?" Board has great action scene showing Superboy with spaceship as missiles fly toward him, and Krypto rides a rocket at the corner. The game ends on a "Kryptonite" square. There is a spinner attached to the cardboard insert and from the board it appears to be a simple spin and move game.

This was one of three games published by Hasbro in 1965 - one each for Batman, Superman and Superboy. SUPERBOY appears to be quite rare and is clearly valued by collectors.

name: Faustus
description:
Doctor Faustus made a pact with the demon, Mephistopheles, to have power over all demons and so become the most powerful magician of all time. You, too, have entered into such a pact, but can you really control what you have unleashed or will they take control of you?

Secrets are power and temptation! Battle with other magicians to ensure that you, and only you, escape the price for such power: Damnation!

Faustus is a game of secrets and temptation. In this game for 3 to 6 players, you take on the role of a magician summoning demons onto yourself and casting them at other magicians whilst tempting them with your hidden secrets. But only one can escape damnation. Only one! One goes free else all are damned!

With two versions of the game and optional rules, this game can be played by both novice and experienced gamers. In the Basic version of the game all that matters on the demons are the numbers; keep your numbers low and doom the rest. In the Advanced game you experience the full power of the demons under your command with each of the 40 Demons offering a unique power that is yours to command while they are in bound to your Pact.

name: Lettres ABCZ
description:
This is a kid game for learning the letters and writing in French.

There is lot of pieces in the form of different objects where the first letter of the word is in-script. There is also letter pieces.

The game have 4 levels:
1) The kid take the objects pieces and name them. The kid who name the more pieces win.
2) The kid associate the object whit the first letter piece. The kid who associate the more objects win.
3) Make pair of 2 objects starting by the same letter. The kid who make the more pairs win.
4) The kid take letters to make words write on a card. The kid who make the most words win.

This game must be play by a adult helping one or multiple kids.

name: Sea Titans
description:
Sea Titans is the 4th installment to the Arena Assault games. Battle in an arena of the future as either Iron Beard the Pirate or Megalotron. Arena Assault is a MASSIVE MULTIPLAYER CARD GAME, meaning there is no maximum number of players. You are only limited by the number of cards you have.
Despite the large number of players the game can handle, gameplay is always fast, fun and furious.
Draw your cards, choose who you want to attack and what attacks cards to play. Defenders may try to defend with defense cards, if available. All Arena Assault games include 20 gear cards. Cards that are available to all that do any number of things.
categories: Card Game, Fighting, Humor, Pirates, Science Fiction

name: Chuba
description:
A game in the Mancala family adapted from Tschuba with a novel starting position. Associated 1891 US patent: number 448,574.

Description following provided by Milton Bradley prior to 1897.

Chuba is an adaptation from a rude game of Eastern Africa which is greatly enjoyed by the natives, who squat on the ground, and play in holes scooped out of the sand, using shells, young coconuts, etc., for counters, which they move from hole to hole.
As now presented to the civilized world for its diversion, Chuba is a game of skill for two players. It is made up of a board with 4 parallel rows or pockets, 11 in each row, and 60 small beads used as men or counters.

...

The winner is the player who captures all his opponent's men."

name: Glory on the Pitch
description:
Welcome to the world of Glory on the Pitch, brought to you by Diggin Deep Sports. With Glory on the Pitch, you can re-create a full soccer match in about ten minutes, complete with the following:
Complete list of goal scorers, time of goals, and assists
Complete set of stats for selected players (Goals, Assists, Shots, Shots on Goal, Yellow Cards, Red Cards)
Complete keeper stats
In game strategies (Who to start? / When to sub? / Who to sub?)
Team Formations (Heavy offense / Heavy Defense / Balanced Attack)
For players that only play one half...Which half to play?
Individual cards means you can have draft leagues, and not be locked into stock teams.
Within five minutes, you’ll have a final score complete with total shots on goal (per half). You also have the option of tracking the stats of up to three players from each squad. An entire match along with stats for certain players can be played in about ten to fifteen minutes.

name: Die Waldwanderung
description:
Objective: be the first reaching target space (Waldhaus = field 60)
- simple 'Roll & Move' game/ moving by turns -
each player moves his/her meeple according die roll
ending on a numbered space (1-20) follow instructions printed cover inside.
Remarks:
Printed in the GDR during 1950's

name: Classic Moves
description:
Basically a "trouble style" game with cards. Classic Moves was developed in the early 1990's by Moore and Moore Industries of London, Ontario. Players begin with 4 marbles in a "safe" zone, and they must be moved around the board to the player's "Home Base".

Movement is accomplished with a 56 card deck, with numbers 1-12, and a number of "wild" cards.

There is a centre "shortcut" that can also be utilized.

Players can also play with a partner, assisting them once their marbles are "home"

name: Seifenkistl Rennen
description:
Objective: be the first reaching target space (field 100)
- simple 'Roll & Move' game/ moving by turns -
each player moves his/her meeple according die roll
ending on a red space follow instructions.
Remarks:
published during 1930's in bavaria or Austria
cute pewter meeples

name: Prinzessin Lillifee: Ein Fest für das Einhorn
description:
In this Princess-Lillifee-themed children's game players try to build garlands as long as possible for the unicorn's birthday party. To do so, players have to collect cards. The 36 cards consist of two parts of different colours (some of them have the same colour on both ends). Players take turns rolling the four colour dice. Dice are then grouped into pairs of two to determine which two cards the player is allowed to take (e.g. if a player rolls orange, yellow, green and green, he/she could take an orange-yellow card and a green-green one). If a player can't use a combination to get a card, he/she removes one card from the game instead.
When all the cards have been distributed, players put together their own cardss like they would put together domino tiles, i.e. with matching ends next to one another. This part of the game is basically a solo puzzle activity.
The player who manages to put together the longest "garland" (row of cards) wins the game.

name: Mighty Morphin Power Rangers: Save Tommy Game
description:
Power Rangers, The evil Rita and Lord Zedd have imprisoned Tommy! It’s up to you to save him. Fight your way through the Evil Space Aliens and Putty Patrol warriors as your travel along the path of the Moon Palace to save Tommy and defeat Rita and Lord Zedd.

Players choose their favorite Mighty Morphin Power Ranger to play as. Each player's ranger has 5 health chips. If they lose battles against the Evil Space Aliens or Putty Patrol warriors, they'll lose one health chip. They'll need land on a Power Ranger space or give up a turn in order to regain health back.

Game play consists of rolling the die and moving your Power Ranger in any direction on the board within the level the players Power Ranger is on. There are four levels to Moon Palace Rangers need to advance through to make it to top to battle Rita and Lord Zedd to save Tommy.

Board spaces include; Power Ranger spaces (regain one health chip back), Putty Patrol warrior spaces (have battle a Putty; roll two dice, higher die wins battle), Evil Space Aliens spaces (they are blocking your Power Rangers path to next level, need acquire the Ready for Action chip in order fight them), and Ready for Action spaces (players need to get each of these within the level they are in, in order to fight the Evil Space Alien that is blocking them from advancing to next level) and blank spaces.

Players Power Rangers will need perform certain dice rolls to obtain a Ready for Action chip and when battling the Evil Space Aliens. Example; Roll either 1, 2 or 3. As your Power Ranger advances through the levels of the game board, they will become be challenging. Players need to obtain at least 4 Ready for Action chips in order to battle the last Evil Space Alien blocking them from reaching top level of the Moon Palace to battle Rita and Lord Zedd to save Tommy.

name: Snoopy Card Game
description:
Snoopy Card Game "With Your Favorite Peanuts Characters" consists of character cards from Charles Schulz's Peanuts comic strips: Charlie Brown, Lucy, Linus, Woodstock and, of course, Snoopy; each character card has a different color background. Players are dealt four cards, which they then play in turn, one at a time, on the gameboard, a 5 x 5 grid. At different points in the game, players claim ownership of a row and a column and, when all spaces are filled, score for their color combinations.
Except for the title and artist (Schulz), this game has no connection to the Milton Bradley game of the same name from 1974.

name: Words of Life
description:
This is an "action Bible game" with a Christian trivia theme.

The educational design features basic doctrine and trivia in a question and answer format. Players use a spinner to move along a rainbow-shaped pathway. A correct response allows the player to advance to the a square matching the color shown on the dial.

Grace cards allow a player to take a bonus move. Sin cards force a player to lose a turn. These cards are mixed into the trivia deck. The first player to land on the "Abundant Life" space is declared the winner.

Includes the board with a spinner, the cards, and tokens.

name: Strike Dice & The Portkey of Chaos
description:
NEW EXPANSION RULES: PORTKEY OF CHAOS

The Basic Strike Dice Game consists of 8 Basic Triangle Cards which carry the Attributes of the Creatures you will meet in the Expansion. These Attributes are also part of the Triangle Bases of the Arena (Gameboard). Next, you will find 32 Pyramid Dice of different color, 8 per player. In the same basic pack you will find and the Strike Dice Expansion: Portkey of Chaos consisting of the 9 Creatures plus the New Rules.


THE GAME

The game here consists of 3 Phases: In each Phase you draw in order 3 Creature Cards. Place the cards on the triangle bases of the board according to which attribute they represent. The creatures carry 2 different numbers: The left number indicates the strength and the right number the Bonus you receive when you kill a Creature. To destroy a Creature you must roll a number with your Pawndie higher from the one which represents his Strength and place it on the opposite Tribase where this Creature is located. When you do that, you draw as many Tricards as the Bonus number this Creature caries on his right side. You keep these cards and you may use them as you wish. Note: The Rules of the Basic Game Apply here too, the only difference is that the Creatures add new elements in the game. You also keep and the Creature you killed since it counts as part of the collected cards. The player with the most cards in the end of 3rd round is the winner.

name: Der Apfelbaum: Ein neues Rechenspiel
description:
Objective: flip balls into holes of different values in the box base & sum up values
- acting by turns -
each player shoots 6 balls summing up gained values;
compared with Flying Hats
balls instead of cones are used - you can't hit the same hole; players are challenged summing up.

name: Welt-Reise-Spiel
description:
objective: journey around the world - be the first ending your round trip in Berlin
- acting by turns -
each player draws 4 (hidden) travel cards; in order to move forward you must play a matching (colour/symbol) card regarding next space; you even may step further if you play another matching one; if you possess a card with a plane (image) you even move three spaces ahead (if it matches).
After end of your turn fill up to 4 cards;
remarks: published end 1950's/early 60's
publishers: Sala, Sala Games, Verlag der Rotsiegelspiele

name: Das bewegliche Verkehrsspiel
description:
Objective: be the first reaching target zone
- acting/moving by turns -
intermediate goal cards are shuffled & distributed; each player moves own car according die roll; move your meeple to the intermediate goals first before heading to target zone; due to die results stop lights (spinner) have to be changed.

remarks:
7th player acts as game master

name: The Feely Game
description:
Tony Blewitt's The Feely Game

The board game that will drive you crazy!

He could be holding a mushroom or an ironing board, she could have a stick of liquorice or a roll of toilet paper. It's up to you to find out in 60 seconds. Sounds easy? Try it out!

Teams have to identify mystery objects that players imagine they are holding in their hands. They ask questions about it ... "Is it big?" ... "Does it move?" ... "Can you eat it?"

This game will bring out powers of quick thinking, memory and also hilarious interpretations of other players' descriptions of everyday objects.

The game is ready to play. Take it home, open it up, gather your friends around and get down to some "FEELY FUN".

name: Eine Reise durch den Schwarzwald
description:
Objective: starting from Karlsruhe be the first ending on space 110 (Stuttgart)
- moving by turn -
simple 'Roll & Move' game - roll the die, move & follow instructions printed on cover inside if your meeple end upon a red marked space.

remarks:
belongs to series: "Scholz' künstlerische Spiele";
meeples: pewter figures

name: Saving On Vacation
description:
A game of travel in a large city with the goal to save as much money possible while having a good time visiting different sights in a large city.

One travels through a designed course on the board landing and visiting different sights to stop on in their vacation travel.

While spending along the way, one tries to save in their travels as well. Whoever gets home earliest gets an 'savings' award and winner is not determined till everyone playing reaches home.

name: Biologie: Lernspiel für Jung und Alt
description: This is a small trivia game by Komet Verlag. It contains 92 cards, with questions about biology. When you answer the questions you can get plus or minus points.

name: Geografische Grundbegriffe: Lernspiel für Jung und Alt
description: This is a small trivia game belonging to the series Wissen-Spielen-Lernen. It contains 98 cards, with questions about geography. When you answer the questions you can get plus or minus points.

name: Tiere der Urzeit: Lernspiel für Jung und Alt
description: This is a small trivia game belonging to the series Wissen-Spielen-Lernen. It contains 98 cards, with questions about dinosaurs. When you answer the questions you can get plus or minus points.

name: Blickpunkt Umwelt: Lernspiel für Jung und Alt
description: This is a small trivia game belonging to the series Wissen-Spielen-Lernen. It contains 98 cards, with questions about the with the environment. When you answer the questions you can get plus or minus points.

name: Naturwissenschaften im Alltag
description: This is a small trivia game belonging to the series Wissen-Spielen-Lernen. It contains 98 cards, with questions about science in everyday life. When you answer the questions you can get plus or minus points.

name: Rekorde der Erde: Lernspiel für Jung und Alt
description: This is a small trivia game belonging to the series Wissen-Spielen-Lernen. It contains 98 cards, with questions about different records. When you answer the questions you can get plus or minus points.

name: To Glory Rise
description:
To Glory Rise is a high speed, no holds barred airship race set in a steampunk world. Players take command of rival airships out to win at any cost. Roll the dice and assign power to your engines and cannons. Head for the gates and the win, but beware your opponents they're bound to have a cannon with your name on it.

The goal of the game is to be the first airship to pass through all of the numbered gates and complete the race, or be the last airship still flying. Players will select rival airships and compete with speed and deadly cannon fire to win the challenge and prove themselves as the world's greatest airship captain.

This tabletop game is designed to be played anywhere you have the time to play. All that is required are the game pieces and a ruler or two, and you can setup a race track and start playing. The game scales for up to six players.

name: Mobility
description:
Unfortunately the game needs a ko rule, and even then it isn't really satisfactory. My friends and family really like it though, so it still might be fun for casuals...

The rules are explained here: http://www.scribd.com/doc/250442316/Mobility

name: Tivoli
description:
Objective: be the first walking through the funfair and leaving it
- simple 'Roll & Move' game/ moving by turns -
each player moves his/her meeple according die roll
ending on a red marked space follow instructions glued on cover inside

name: Gridiron Dice
description:
Are you ready for some football dice? Gridiron Dice is a fast paced push your luck style dice game. Players take turns grabbing custom dice and rolling to reach first down. There are three kinds of dice; easy dice with the least number of sacks and incompletes on them, normal dice with longer yardage but more chance of receiving an incomplete, and hard dice with the worst odds and biggest payout of them all.

If you don't make a first down in your first three dice, you can choose to grab a fourth and roll, or punt the ball. Advancing their marker down the field they try to reach the endzone, or at least get in field goal range. First player to 30 points wins in a normal game.

name: STRYKER: US Mechanized Operations in the War on Terror
description:
STRYKER-20 puts you in command of a US Army Stryker mechanized unit against an OPFOR (Opposition Forces) formation. This is a two player game: US Player and OPFOR Player. The US Player controls the Stryker Combat Team. There are two levels of scenario: Company Commander to provide an introduction to the missions; and battalion, to provide a full simulation.

The Opposition Forces (OPFOR) player controls enemy units and also manages various randomized incidents within the area of operations. The game also can be played by teams of players, each commanding different element of a force. 

As much as possible, STRYKER uses standard US military terminology to create a simulation experience that can be used by service members with a minimum of special knowledge of gaming, and can also be used to train civilian personnel in military procedure.

General Course of Play

Each player selects a Mission card from the deck. You organize your Stryker Combat Team, which, depending on the scenario, may be one company, two companies, or a full battalion. You then deploy your Team on the game map. 

The basic unit in the game is a platoon (some units represent smaller teams/squads). There are also markers representing various kinds of Fire and Surveillance Support, as well as civilians and items which would appear in a combat zone. 

The game is played in scenarios, called Missions. To win a scenario, you must accomplish your mission objective.

name: Marine Global Response
description:
Marine Global Response (MGR) is a fast-paced game that challenges players with the operations, orders, and opposition faced in twelve different 21st-century theatres. 

The game is played solitaire, with a typical campaign requiring 45 minutes to two hours to play. A few of the largest campaigns could stretch to four hours or so.

The game engine has simple systems for geography, human terrain, and operational personality unique to each campaign (theatre) represented. The player takes the role of the colonel in charge of a Marine Expeditionary Unit (MEU), a reinforced brigade capable of independent operation. The player selects a Campaign from the Campaign pool. This pool is composed of twelve cards each detailing a hot spot selected for its interesting nature and probability of US ground force involvement in the foreseeable future. The hot spots include Venezuela, Liberia, Mexico, South Korea, Egypt, and Gaza.

An expeditionary unit’s force composition is variable. After selecting a Campaign card, the player then selects appropriate forces and takes the unit counters for those forces for use during the game. The player takes markers for opposition forces (OpFor) and geography relevant to the Campaign, and sets those into pools for use, as well. Player forces are predominantly ground units, with some air units for supply, transport, and fire support. Naval forces are not represented, though some of the ground forces have amphibious capability.

Play takes place on the OpsDisplay (map) which uses boxes, tables, and other features to manage the information, systems, and battle spaces portrayed in the game.

Each unit typically represents a platoon (about 40 marines) or a handful (2 to 4) helicopters or fixed-wing aircraft. Units begin in the Bravo Base box on the OpsDisplay. As the player is assigned Operations, he or she deploys forces from Bravo Base to tracks containing said Operations to meet their respective conditions.

The game is played in a series of turns that represents days or weeks. Each turn introduces an Operation to which the player assigns forces. These forces carry out Missions with the objective of completing the Operation. Each Operation completed yields a measure of success towards the objectives of the Campaign. The Campaign concludes when a set number of Operations is complete. Victory is determined by how effectively the player met the challenges of each Operation.

Each Operation is resolved by maneuvering units on a track of six boxes. The player carries out Missions for only one Operation on a single track at a time. Each track is composed of six boxes, called Grids. A Grid represents a small area, perhaps a few hundred square kilometers typified by a single, prevailing terrain or community. As an Operation’s milestones are met, the player’s forces move farther down that Operation’s track.

The player may carry out as many as six Operations at a time. At that pace, the player’s forces will be stretched very thin. Continuous operations will exhaust units, as will enemy action. Units can recover at Bravo Base either at the conclusion of an Operation or by pulling out of the Operation prior to completion. Bravo Base is more than an area for staging and R&R. The player may also have units conduct Rehearsals to improve their respective effectiveness in one of the four capabilities.

Unlike a typical wargame, combat is only one of four primary functions of each unit. Units are rated on the bases of Kinetics (combat), ISR (Intelligence, Surveillance, Reconnaissance), CIMIC (Civil-Military Cooperation), and Engineering. The nature of a unit determines its effectiveness in each of these four capabilities. Each unit’s effectiveness is portrayed numerically with a value of zero (no capability) to an upper-limit of five or so. A tank platoon might have capabilities of 5 0 0 0, while a Special Operations team might have values of 2 4 2 0. The tank platoon, with a Kinetics rating of 5, is peerless in a stand-up fight, but has no other capabilities. The Special Operations team can fight, but is much better at gathering Intel.

In most of the Campaigns represented in the game, the role of the MEU is more than just combat. The MGR design focuses on the broader range of missions faced by Marine commanders, including distinguishing bad guys from good guys, establishing bases, gathering intelligence, and gaining the trust and support of the locals.

Units that are not controlled by the player are collectively referred to as Opposition Forces (OpFor). The composition of OpFor is another aspect of MGR that departs from typical wargame design. OpFor units are composed predominantly of non-combatants. Shooting is easy. Separating legitimate targets from civilians is not. As the player’s forces enter a Grid, the player will typically exert significant effort to identify the human terrain of the Grid, assess the risk, and take necessary action to establish required security.

name: Die Reise ins Himmelreich
description:
Objective: be the first ending upon space '100'
- moving by turns -
translation: 'journey into kingdom of heaven'
It is a simple game of racing with lovely illustrations. The main principle is one shared with Snakes and Ladders, but not using a spiral track; virtue is rewarded and vice is punished.
remarks:
should be published ~ 1900;
comparable also with the well known 'Reise in die Ewigkeit' games (journey into eternity) from that period,similar to Die Reise in das Himmelreich

name: The County Fair: A Money Game for Boys and Girls
description:
Objective: be the first ending a walk through the country fair park - learn how to pay cash
- acting by turns -
active player moves according die roll: ending on any space turn the spinner; red space => consult inner ring - other colours => consult outer ring for directions except when indicated on stops.

name: Bluffoons
description:
Combining some luck and a little skill, Bluffoons is a mix of fantastic bluffing games rolled into one great party game. Using dice, cards, mindgames and general skullduggery, players pit their wits, chance their arm and push their luck to the limit in an attempt to be crowned top bluffooner. An unreadable poker face and nerves of steel will also come in handy.

Bluffoons: a game of bluff, played by buffoons.
Buffoon: joker, jester, clown, wag, bozo.
Bluff: bamboozle, hoodwink, double-cross, confound, baffle.

There are five first-rate bluffing categories, so everyone will have their own favourite. Sometimes you play a DUEL (one against one), sometimes it’s ALL PLAY (everyone plays) and sometimes you play ‘BLIND’ (with no idea of what you have). So whether you are trying to imply that you have drawn the highest card, establishing if your opponent really has rolled a pair of sixes or double-crossing someone despite agreeing to cooperate, Bluffoons will challenge not only your bluffing ability but also your buffooning potential to the maximum.

name: Deal or No Deal: Secret Cases
description:
From the publisher:
Deal or No Deal - Secret Cases is a great new family game and a brand new way to play the hit TV game show. Just like the show, there are 26 brief cases that hide 26 value cards and plenty of money to be won. But in Secret Cases you have the added fun of making a deal on every turn and the nail-biting tension of trying to bluff and trick your opponents. And as the game progresses you´ll find there are secrets all around the table that really build the excitement.
categories: Bluffing, Card Game, Movies / TV / Radio theme

name: Cuble
description:
This is a nicely produced game with sturdy plastic tiles, that are laid out to form pleasing patterns. The aim is to play out tiles so as to score a cuble which happens when the three adjacent numbers form a sum (like 7, 4, 3 which is 3 + 4 = 7). The rules and game play are easy, but keep everyone alert and engaged. There is scope for a little tactical play by seeing what numbers are still available. A fun way to learn some maths and enjoy family time together. (Source: Boardgames Australia)

This game was short-listed for the Best Australian Game 2011 award.

name: Femigoa Trigoa
description:
Advertising edition of Activity kompakt for a drug company from Leipzig: Leipziger Arzneimittelwerk burner Epeka.

Players have to describe words verbal, pantomimic or by drawing.
Teammates must guess player's descriptions to score a point. Team with the most cards wins.
mechanics: Acting, Dice Rolling, Line Drawing, Team-Based Game

name: TicTo
description:
TicTo is a Greek verb that means, "I do" or "I work". TicTo is also a strategy game in 3 dimensions.

The board recreates a city of Greek ground plant, the counters are its inhabitants and the rules their legislation. The game begins with a established order that, when modified, turns into a labyrinth.

The game's objective is the construction of a way to lead the head counter to the departure position of the opponent. The counters do the way and block up the opponent's way.

name: Ach, du dickes Gummibärchen
description:
A licensed game by Haribo, the makers of gummi bears. Its a sort of three card monte for children. A yellow, a green and a red ball made out of a plush material are hidden under three blue plastic cups. The cups are moved around and the players must guess where each colour ended up.

From the box back:
At the gummi bear three card monte championship all players look concentrated how one of the participants moves the cups that hide the three coloured balls around. Who is really observant knows under which cup there is the green, the red and the yellow ball and can win. But it is not rare that the players make wrong guesses!

name: Loop
description:
In the game, there are 72 cards in 4 colors and with the values ​​0 to 5. Players are dealt four cards in hand and are trying to get rid of the cards as fast as possible, or at least collect as few points as possible.

Stacks are formed in the middle of the table for depositing discards; there can only be one stack per color. A stack starts with 0 or 1. A discarded card must have the same value, 1 higher, or 1 lower than the previous card, as well as the same color (example: yellow 3 on yellow 4 or yellow 2). If possible, you can lay down several cards in on turn, but only on one pile. You can also pass and draw a card from the draw pile, or place a card face down as "waste" in front of you and draw a card from the draw pile.

A player who discards his last card, or who draws the last card from the draw pile ends the round. Whoever discards the last card gets 0 points. Everyone else writes down the value of the remaining cards in hand +2 points per waste card. After 10 rounds the player with the fewest points wins.

From the Austrian Games Museum Ludorium:
Loop is primarily interesting as an example of a game from India, the German team of authors Kirsten Becker and Jens-Peter Schliemann have been working with the Indian publisher since winter 2007. Parksons is trying to offer a program of educational games and family games in India. Loop combines well-known mechanisms into a brisk card-shedding game in the tradition of Ligretto and other such games. Graphics, material and workmanship are attractive, the rules of the game are in English.

name: Spread the Word
description:
Word game in the style of crossword puzzles.

You have 9 cards in hand and try to play as many connected words as possible. Then you draw back up to to 9 cards in hand again. Next turn, you can lengthen words, transform them into new words, or skip your move to swap cards in hand from the draw pile. A player can appeal the word of another player. If the appeal is justified, the player loses 10 points. Words scores points depending on the length, from 20 points for 2-letter words to 90 points for 9-letter words. No word can reach over a red barrier on a card.

The player with the most points at the end of the game wins.

name: Packeropoly
description: Monopoly variant featuring businesses of West Fargo, North Dakota. The Packer is the mascot of West Fargo High School. The game was a fundraiser for the high school DECA club.
mechanics: Auction/Bidding, Dice Rolling, Roll / Spin and Move, Set Collection, Stock Holding, Trading

name: Her Majesty's Clockwork Tournament
description:
The Queen has need of your services, tinkerer. Whosoever can demonstrate the greatest ingenuity and build the most amazing gizmos will win her favour and become the new Minister of Clockwork.

Roll the dice and place gears to build a machine that will earn you coins, dice or wrenches. Press your luck as you race to impress her majesty by engineering the unlikeliest of machines.

Three modes (Hindenberg, Tesla & Eisntein) let you play fast & loose, add some strategy, or take it to the max.

Each turn, roll your dice which have different combinations of gears on each face. Place one or more of them and then repeat, rerolling the rest, placing and rerolling until they're all on the board. Each machine that you connect to the driver gear gives you a reward. Pick up all your dice at the end of each turn—except for dice which rolled the locked face and remain permanently, affecting how both you and your opponent play.

Get cracking, chap!
categories: Dice, Industry / Manufacturing, Renaissance, Science Fiction
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Network and Route Building, Push Your Luck

name: Uroboros
description:
Introduction

Uroboros is an ancient symbol depicting a serpent eating its own tail.

Uroboros is a 2 player area enclosure game played on the spaces of a 7×9 board and a supply of black and white stones.

Play

The game begins with an empty board.

Players choose a color: White or Black.

Starting with White, a player’s first stone is placed on any empty space.

A player’s second stone is placed adjacent (orthogonally or diagonally) to their first stone.

* This determines a “movement direction”, e.g. east. A player will typically continue placing stones in the same direction, creating a long snake-like group as play progresses.

For each later stone, a player may place a new stone adjacent to the previous stone in the same direction as the previous stone was placed (e.g. also east), or changes direction, skipping one space (occupied or empty) and placing the new stone in the space (which must be empty) immediately after the skipped space.

Play continues in this fashion until the last player able to place a stone wins.
mechanics: Area Majority / Influence, Enclosure, Tile Placement

name: Rainbow: A Game With Colour Cards
description:
Card game of using colours to make other colours.

Deal out all the cards evenly but include the Dummy as an extra hand. Give each player 30 counters. At the start, each player puts 10 counters into the Pool. The Dummy hand is left face-down.

Each player, in their turn, can ask any other player for a card by naming the colour he would like. If successful, that player can ask again, and so on until he gets a negative answer. If this happens he must 'Buy' a card from the Dummy (by paying one counter into the Pool) and add it to his hand. If a set is acquired during his turn then he must expose it by laying down the correct cards (Master Card plus the two colour cards needed to make that Master Card colour. For instance, 1 Yellow + 1 Green makes Blue. For every colour set that a player exposes, he gets a number of counters from the Pool. This varies with the sets exposed, but will result in taking 4, 3 or 2 counters.

One set is different, the Rainbow set, which comprises of the Rainbow Master Card and the rainbows 6 colours (I know there arte 7 colours in a rainbow but the designer of this game did not know that). The round ends when a player lays down the Rainbow set and he or she takes the Pool and every other player must hand over counters for every card still in their hand (1 counter for a colour card, 2 for a Master Card.)

Play as many rounds as there are players and the winner is the one with the most counters.

An alternative way of scoring is given that awards points instead of counters and a further, easier game, called Rainbow Sequence, is described.

name: Stress Attack
description:
The object of STRESS ATTACK is to be the first to complete four stages of stress (childhood stress, school stress, job stress, and lovelife stress) in order. Usually, players roll and move around a board, taking various kinds of cards, losing turns, and so on. When a player lands on an appropriate space on the board, she can enter the appropriate subgame for her next stage of stress.

In the subgame, players move along a short path by rolling a die; after each roll, they must draw a card describing a stressful situation of the appropriate type and then demonstrate to the satisfaction of the other players how they would use a stress technique determined by a roll of the die to help cope with the stress of the specified situation.

name: Reado
description: Reado is a Bingo variant where the entries are Dewey Decimal classifications. The caller gives a letter (R, E, A, D, or O) and the title of a work, for example "R -- The Complete Plays of Shakespeare." Any player who has the appropriate Dewey Decimal number for that work (in this case 800) in their R column marks it on their Reado board. A player wins when she gets 5 in a row horizontally, vertically, or diagonally.

name: Historical Pope Joan
description:
A card game but without the board associated with Pope Joan games. And the cards are not traditional at all. They feature British Royal 'houses', such as the Normans or the Tudors, etc. Because of the uneven number of monarchs in each family, the suits are uneven. For example, the Norman suit consists of five cards, four being monarchs and the fifth is an honour card and features illustrations of the four monarchs in that House. However the Tudors consist of 6 cards; Five monarchs and the honour card showing them all. Others vary according to how many monarchs were in that lineage.

Mark out on the table four areas (called Pools). In order they signify;
Ace of Fleur-de-Lis or William the Norman
The 5 of the Red and White Rose, which is represented by Elizabeth the 1st
The five of the Oak, represented by William IV
and just one known as Game
Each player puts 1 counter into the William the Norman Pool and 1 into Elizabeth Pool and 1 into the Game Pool. And each player puts two counters into the William IV Pool.

The game is one of following suit really. If a card is chosen as the first card in a suit, the 'next' card in the suit can be played on it, and so on. If the highest card in a suit is played. that player can choose to start with a card in one of the other suits. Play goes on until one player plays their last card. That player gets the Game counters. In addition, every player pays the 'out' player one counter for every card still in their hand (or two counters for every card if you happen to still hold the Cromwell card) The other Pools are collected during the game. If a player plays the next card in sequence and that card happens to be William the Norman, Elizabeth or William IV, then that player takes the counters in the associated Pool.

Play as many games as you want and the one with the most counters when you stop, is the winner.

Notes:
There are seven suits:
Fleur-de-Lis (sic) or the Norman line
Broom Tree or the Plantagenets
Red Rose or the House of Lancaster
White Rose or the House of York
Red and White Rose joined or the House of Tudor
Thistle or the House of Stuart
Acorn or the House of Hanover
Plus one special card representing Oliver Cromwell (the Usurper as the rules describe him). He does not belong to a royal house at all so does not have an emblem. He can only be played between the two Charles cards. In other words, when Charles I is played, then Cromwell can be played and then Charles II could be played. If you are caught with Cromwell in your hand then you have to pay double for the cards in your hand once someone has gone out.

There are 42 cards and the rules run to 16 pages but do include a sample game. That must have been pretty rare. I have dated it 1838 because the last Monarch is William IV and Victoria was crowned a year later.

name: Skirmish Word Game
description:
This game could be described as Battleship with words. The board is a bi-fold, with a ribbon connecting the two sides to provide support for tenting on a table. Each side of the board has two areas - the lower portion contains a thin ledge on which to place the letter tiles and a coordinate system. The upper portion has the coordinates as well as holes which can be filled with either light or dark pegs, depending on on the result of a query. The letter tiles, which come in two shades, are imprinted on a quadrille rule themselves, for better alignment with the coordinate system.

The game plays by each person placing a word made from their color of tiles, in secret, on their side of the board, and then the players take turns calling out coordinates. A player records a "hit" with a light peg, and a "miss" with a darker one. The first player to guess the other's word is the winner.
publishers: KMS Industries Inc. Scientific Games Div.

name: Karussell
description:
A simple family action game .
6 coloured balls should be placed in holes by a spinning top.
Under the lucent platter are colours. For each ball of the same colour than printed below, the player will get a chip of the corresponding colour.

Goal is, to collect 3 chips of each colour.
Reimplemented in 1975 as Blumengarten. Game mechanism is the same. Karussell is abstract and has no theme, Blumengarten uses flowers tiles instead of ordinary plastic chips.

name: Safety First
description:
Card game that has nothing to do with teaching children safety first (as most similar titled games do) but the cards do make use of roadside imagery even if the theme is not followed through into the rules.

VALUE OF CENTRE CARDS
Beacon (Highest card) scores 5 Points
Stop (Second card) loses 4 Points
Caution (Third card) loses 3 Points
Go (Fourth card) scores 2 Points
Bobbie (Fifth card) scores 1 Point
Each pack consists of 20 centre cards, and 36 other cards numbered 2 to 9 in orange, red, green and black.

To commence playing, all the above centre cards must be placed face downwards in the centre of the table. Deal out nine to each player of the remainder of the cards. If more than four players, deal round until all the playing cards have been dealt. Dealer commences playing by leading his smallest card in any suit. Should he lead a red two and be holds the three in his own hand, he can follow immediately with it, and the four also, if he holds it. Should he lead the two, not holding the three, the next player on his left follows. He must either play the three of the same suit, or pick up a card from the centre of the table.
Should a Beacon card be picked up, the player registers on the score card 5 points, and continues to play with his lowest card in any suit. Next player then either follows suit or picks up a centre card.
Should a Stop card be picked up, the player deducts four points on his score card, and loses his turn to play. The next player then either following suit with the three or picking up a centre card. Should a Caution card be picked up, the player loses three points on his score card, but continues to play his lowest card (in any suit), the next player again following suit or picking up a centre card.
Should a Go card be picked up, he scores two points and continues playing his lowest card in any suit.
Should a Bobbie card be picked up, the player registers one point, and continues to play any low card.
Any player playing the ten in any suit is allowed to go again with any low card.
The player who chips first (i.e., uses all his cards up), adds 20 points to his score.

The player, who, after deducting his losses, scores 50 points is the winner.

Should there be insufficient centre cards, all scores to be added or deducted, and the cards collected, shuffled, and replaced face downwards in the centre of the table. All centre cards must be kept separate in play, and it is in the interest of each player to keep all cards, except the last one played, covered up.

name: Hunt the Ghost
description:
An early Victorian board game, probably inspired by games such as Fox & Geese where it pits one player against the rest.

One player is the Ghost and the rest of the players are hunters. The Ghost is placed in the central diamond on the board and the playing pieces of the other players in the five diamonds nearest the Ferry (but not across the water). The movements are diamond to diamond through the lines joining them and you can cross from one circular line to another when there is a line linking them. The cards can not cross water anywhere but the Ghost may do so by following the dotted lines.

Ghost wins the game if he succeeds in crossing the water to the part of the country at the top of the board. The Hunters win if they surround the Ghost and force him on to the diamond at either of the two houses with diamonds, or on to the either of the two diamonds at the Cave, or on to the centre diamond so that he cannot escape.

The Ghost moves first and then the Hunters, then the Ghost again, and so on. Neither the Ghost or Hunters can be taken. Everyone can move backwards or forwards, but only one move each turn. (I assume that you can only move into empty diamonds and not occupied ones.

name: Poles and Russians
description:
Abstract game for two players. One takes the Pole playing pieces, the other the Russians. The Poles are lighter in appearance, the Russians darker. Each player puts his men on the spaces marked with an X on his side of the board.

The object is to capture all your opponent's pieces.The men move forwards (or sideways I suspect but the rules are not clear on this) one space at a time. The Captains can move backwards or forwards. No Captains are in play at the start. You capture men by jumping over them, as in Draughts or Checkers. When either player gets a man into the Battlefield (up the centre of the board) that man is changed into a Captain and is placed at the uppermost spot on the outside of the board. Now he can move backwards or forwards but still only one space at a time (unless jumping to capture). Capturing must be done if you are in place to do so.

name: West Point A Game For The Nation
description:
The game is a rather simple roll and move game. It has 43 spaces arranged in a triangle. Some spaces are marked with a cannon ball or a star. The cannon ball marked spaces are penalty spaces. Lose a turn, go back spaces and so on. the star marked spaces predict good fortune for the player but bestow no advantage in the game itself.

The game uses one six sided die (1-6) for determining the number of spaces to move. The game sample has two dice cups so there may have been more than one die originally. The markers are red, black, yellow, and green.

The game box is mostly red with the title in yellow. A West Point Cadet in full dress is standing at attention with a bayoneted musket.

name: Bull's Eye: The Square Way to Success
description: Bull's Eye is a simple roll-and-move played on a 7x7 grid printed on cardstock. The cells are numbered 1-48 and the very center one is labelled "BULL'S EYE". Players use the included pawns and single die to race around the spiral to the center. Four numbers have special instructions - lose a turn, go back four spaces, free throw and go ahead five spaces. An exact roll is required to enter the winning space. If one player arrives at a space that is already occupied, both players roll the die. The player with the highest number advances his pawn the number of spaces rolled.

name: 123 Dice
description:
123 Dice Game by Collective Wisdom

This small-box game has eight 1" dice with large numbers ranging from 1-72. Rules for 14 games and a few variations are included. All are math games designed for preschool through fourth grade. They are:

________________________________________
Preschool - 1st Grade:

Number Identification Game - Roll the dice and name the numbers, earning a point for each number correctly identified.

Order of Numbers Game - Roll all dice, re-rolling duplicates. Put the dice in numerical order. Earn one point per roll and play to five.

Counting Game - Roll all dice except the "81" die. Select any two dice and say aloud all the numbers between them. Earn one point per roll.
________________________________________
Games and Activities for 1st and 2nd Grades:

Another More Challenging Counting Game - Plays as "Counting Game" above except that a point is earned for each number named, encouraging players to select dice that are further apart.

Blind Toss Number Value Game - A moderator rolls all the dice and gives one to each player whose eyes are shut. Each player then goes around the circle, saying whether their number is greater than or less than each other player's die. If his is less than any player, he is eliminated. Eventually, one player will remain in the round and earn one point. This is repeated except that the lowest number will win the second round. Continue until a single player scores six.

Odd Even Game - Roll all dice and divide them into even and odd piles. Earn one point for each roll.

Addition Game (Adding 2 numbers) - Roll all dice. Select two, add them and announce the sum. One point is given for each correct answer. Play to ten points.

Addition and Subtraction - As above for Addition Game, but continue, subtracting the lesser die from the greater die and announcing the difference. One point is given for each correct answer. Play to ten points.

Addition Game (Adding 3 Numbers) - Roll all dice and choose three. Add them together and announce the sum.

Challenging Variation of Additiona & Subtraction Games - Instead of granting one point per correct answer, players earn the answer as the number of points, thus encouraging players to select harder dice.

Place Value Game - Roll dice until all show single-digit numbers. Select any three and name the three-digit number they form. Earn one point for each roll and play to 28. Optionally, offer an extra point for each number that is written out long-hand.

________________________________________
Games and Activities for 3rd and 4th Grades:

Multiplication Game I: Each player writes down a set of five numbers. Before rolling, each player will announce which of those numbers they will be using. After rolling all the dice, select three and multiply each by the number chosen before the roll, scoring one point per correct answer. On his next turn, the player must choose a new multiplicand.

Multiplication Game II: Roll six dice. Divide the rolled dice into three pairs and multiply each pair, announcing the product. Earn one point per correct answer.

Challenging Variation to Multiplication Games I and II: Play as above except that players add the products to their scores instead of one point, thus challenging them to select higher-yielding combinations.

Division Game: Roll all dice, removing any duplicate numbers. Identify any pairs of dice where one can be evenly divided into the other. Die may be used more than once. Earn one point per pair identified. Before the next player rolls the dice, they may review the pairs and earn two points for any missed pairs they identify. Play to 30 points.

Equation Game: Roll all dice. Identify any valid equations - addition, subtraction, multiplication or division. Each equation will require at least three dice, but may use more. Earn one point for each die used. Continue making equations, re-using dice as needed. Play to 25 points.

________________________________________
The dice are of good quality and have the following faces:

A: 1 - 2 - 3 - 4 - 5 - 6
B: 2 - 3 - 4 - 5 - 8 - 9
C: 2 - 9 - 10 - 10 - 11 - 12
D: 3 - 4 - 5 - 6 - 7 - 8
E: 3 - 5 - 6 - 7 - 9 - 10
F: 8 - 8 - 16 - 24 - 32 - 40
G: 9 - 18 - 36 - 54 - 72 - 81
H: 10 - 15 - 20 - 25 - 30 - 40

name: Apocalypse: Zombie Edition
description:
Description:
The zombie hordes have swept the world, humanity is barely hanging on, now is your chance to rule!!
All you have to do is survive, horde your resources and then find a nice mall or small town that you can rule with an iron fist. Fight zombies, sabotage your fellow survivors and ensure that you are the on top when all the undead dust settles.
Apocalypse is an exciting new collectable card game, where 2 or more players take turns battling zombies, gathering resources, and stabbing each other in the back. Find items like food and weapons, use zombie bait on your opponents, refresh yourself with the world's most aggressive energy drink, Prison Rape brand energy drinks. Expand your Apocalypse with the upcoming set Going Nuclear! The zombies are only the beginning.

2-4 players recommended for a 60 card deck, for more players just add more cards.

name: The FORE! Horsemen
description:
After the humans went and got themselves all Zombified, the Four Horsemen are left with lots and lots of free time. Following failed attempts at other leisure activities, they are giving mini-golf a try. Unfortunately, sportsmanship is a concept Death, War, Pestilence, and Famine have a difficult time grasping...

You and your fellow horsemen start the game on the first hole. Each turn you roll your bones and move by matching the symbols on the board. But, winning isn't easy against cheaters like the horsemen! Use your "FORE! stones" whenever you want to instantly knock another horseman's ball back to the last hole.

Win the game by being the first horseman to complete the 9th hole!

name: Frankie
description:
Franklin is the worse lab assistant EVER! Of course HE would be hit by lightning! How are you suppose to fire someone when he's just been fried!?!? The first step is putting him back together, and quickly too - you're going to need that lightning to restart the bone-head once you sew him back together... You did go to med-school right? Pre-med? Took home-ec? Oh no this isn't good at all... Man, did he just get hit AGAIN? Come on everyone, quickly now....

The game starts with that bone-headed lab assistant Frankie laying on the ground. The storm is raging and you're racing to put him back together before it passes. On your turn, pick a symbol, pick a partner to work with you, and roll your bones! If your combined roll shows the right combination, you have successfully mended one of Frankie's parts. Yay! If you don't, the storm keeps coming and the lightning rains down! But be careful, if more lightning hits Frankie before you're ready, some of your hard work will come undone!

Are your fellow scientists and co-workers missing in action? Well then it's up to you to fix Frankie all by yourself - roll all of the bones and with just a pinch of luck, you alone can put him back together!

Frankie is a co-operative game with all of the players working together against the storm tracker (timer). Win the game by successfully repairing all of Frankie's parts before the storm passes!
mechanics: Cooperative Game, Dice Rolling, Team-Based Game

name: Scared Sheet-Less
description:
Moving into a new house is so exciting, especially one in a brand new neighborhood! People are moving in from all over the world... and so are the ghosts. Unfortunately, this town isn't big enough to contain so many spirits! The solution? Only the most scary, sheety ghost can stay. That's right, a real-life, astral scare-off! Thankfully, most of the new houses have full linen closets!

In Scared Sheetless, scaring is the name of the game! But let's face it, there's nothing scary about a naked ghost. The game starts out with you and your ghostly competitors alone in the new neighborhood, a neighborhood only big enough for one ghost. On your turn, roll your bones. Doubles reveal new sheets and the rest of your roll is movement. Match the symbols to move from house to house, picking up sheets and scaring your fellow ghosts as you go!

Win the game by being the last sheet-ed ghost!

name: That's A Wrap!
description:
Exploring a newly discovered tomb is so exciting! The hieroglyphs, the architecture, the sarcophagus... And... and the Mummy! Oh no, no no! Run! A brilliant idea, only foiled by the echoing thud of a dozen stone doors slamming shut! Need some keys. Oh man, keys, keys, keys! Quick!

The game starts off with you and your friends in the central chamber of a massive tomb - with the Mummy you just woke up! Oh no! Roll your bones and move as quick as you can because once he gets his bearings, the Mummy will be after you! You'll need to roll a key to pass through the locks and escape, but the mummy takes part of your rolls making those keys even harder to find!

The first person out of the tomb wins the game!
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Roll / Spin and Move

name: Where-Wolf?
description:
It's not easy being a werewolf, but you've learned how to make a life. Keep a low profile, don't chase the neighbors, etc... Unfortunately, it seems somewolf else hasn't learned that yet. And now the town's in an uproar over the mess left in the middle of town, and something must be done! The plan: head out into the woods on the next full moon and catch the wolf! The problem, everyone has to be there - including you! So you need to catch the other wolf before someone catches you. But what you don't know: your lovely town of Wolfeboro is inhabited entirely by werewolves and all of your neighbors are facing your same dilemma - catch or be caught!

Before the game begins, you and your friends must work together to create the Wolfeboro woods - every player gets a say in how many trees you use and where they go! Yay! And then its time to hunt down one of your friends before they can hunt you! Each turn, roll your bones to move, but be careful, the wrong roll means you get hit by moonlight and become the prey.

The first player to catch a w(h)erewolf wins the game!

name: Zombified
description:
Zombified is a 4-10 player elimination game.

Let's face it, there's no good explanation. You and your friends are locked in a silo with a broken jar of Zombie-Maker-243. The end result is a no-brainer: it's only a matter of time until you're all infected. But hey, why not make your last moments fun? After all, when it comes to tag, zombies really bite!

You and your friends start the game locked inside an abondoned military silo contaminated with Zombie-Maker-243. It's inevitable that you'll become a zombie, but that's not exactly the life choice that you prefer! Each turn, you roll your bones to run away from your (former) friends, but you'd better roll lucky: getting the wrong symbols means you've been contaminated and, BAM!, are instantly Zombified!

Zombified can also be played by groups even larger than 10 people! The central logo-staircase allows movement between the silo's underground floors. While there is no limit to the number of floors you can play on, a minimum of 5 people per floor is recommended.

The last player to become Zombified is the winner!

name: The Stake-Out
description:
The Stake-Out is a 2 player unequal-forces strategy game.

That darn Vampire has gone too far! With his flowing locks, eye-liner, and accent, he's setting the bar too high and the women-folk aren't willing to marry a simple guy anymore. They want poetry and compliments, charm and *ugh* romance! *shudder* Enough is enough! It's time for us villagers to stand together, put him in his place (and make sure he stays this time!)! He can't kill us all... right?

The Stake-Out starts with the Villagers pouring into the Vampire's lair and the unaware Vampire napping peacefully in his coffin. Moving slowly and staying out of the shadows, the Villagers need to surround the Vampire in order to stake their claim. The Vampire flies in shadows, taking out the villagers that stray too far from the group.

The Villagers win by surrounding the Vampire with at least 3 pieces. The Vampire wins by not being staked (and hopefully eating all of the Villagers!)!

name: Them Bones
description:
Them Bones is a 4 player perfect-information strategy game.

While the bone yard isn't a lively place, it's most definitely an active one, especially the underground scene! And all that activity has come to a head now that it's Halloween night. The Necromancer has returned to this unhallowed yard with his once-yearly promise to revive ONE skeleton. Factions have been established, lines drawn, and the fight is on! And you'll be damned if he picks somebony else AGAIN!

Them Bones starts off like any normal graveyard - with all of the skeletons in their graves. But the necromancer is coming and only ONE skeleton will get a second chance at life. You'll have to work together with your competitors to eliminate other skeletons, but it'll be up to you alone to take and hold the central Masoleum while the necormancer casts his spell. Don't forget to use of the graveyard's underground tunnel network to move between graves and get the jump on your competition!

Skeletons are captured by being surrounded by any two opposing skeletons (mixed-force captures are allowed!). The first player to capture and hold the center space for one full round wins the game!

name: From Log Cabin To White House
description: Each player takes one piece, and puts it on the Log Cabin. At the beginning of the game each player must spin a one to advance to the first square. All plays are made in turn, moving the number of squares spun with the dial. Each square represents an office, and a progress to the White House. If a player stops on a square indicating a promotion or a setback, the player moves forward or backward to the square named. If sent to the Log Cabin, the player must begin over again. If sent to Court the player removes his or her piece to the Jury corner, and spins in turn the Jury dial to get the verdict of the Jury. The player must abide by this verdict, doing as the dial directs. The player first reaching the White House at the centre, moving there exactly for his or her spin, will be President, and win the game.

name: Newport Yacht Race Game
description:
IMPLEMENTS:
Two differently numbered yachts
An indicator with an arrow

Each player takes a yacht and the plays in turn, according to the rules.
Each player must spin a 5 to enter the yacht at space 1 but if later on he is compelled to start over again by stopping on either space 4 or 15 the player may enter on any spin.

If a yacht stops on a gold space it gains two points, going to the next gold space.

If a yacht stops on a red space the player loses his/her turn.

If two yachts wind up on the same space, the first yacht is "blanketed" and goes back 4 spaces.

If a yacht becomes disabled by landing on space 27 it moves forward at 1/2 spinner speed rounded up for the remainder of the game unless a 6 is rolled which repairs the yacht and then on the next turn the yacht returns to normal speed. Players stopping on spaces containing directions must always move according to those directions except for those landing on space 27 (disabled)

First player to reach space 40 wins the race

Game submission should be credited to KEVIN Kluvon KG who sent me the info on the game

name: Best 'N Show
description: Simulates the dog show circuit life. Players roll a die and move, encountering various expenses and bonuses. At several points, you may participate in regional Dog Shows, possibly acquiring points (the rules are rather sketchy). Once you have 15 points, you may attempt to enter the Best Minster K.C. show in the center of the board, where you win the game if you correctly guess the [breed] Group which has won 'Best In Show'; if you do not win, you collect all the money on the board (how it gets there is not mentioned) and return to the circuit.

name: Jungle Gold Game
description: Players take turns spinning a spinner and moving the number of spaces shown. When they spin 'Return to Start', they do, and take the number of points shown on the space they're leaving, or lose 10 points if they were already on 'Start'. A few other spaces have other effects, and a player landing on an occupied space moves back two spaces instead. First to 250 points wins.
publishers: (Unknown), Five Star Toys, Tee Pee Toys, Jessup Paper Box Co., Warren Built Rite Games

name: Futbolmate
description:
Soccer is the sport that probably has more followers in the world, so it's a great challenge for all board game designers to reproduce the emotion of the goal. Futbolmate is an innovative option in which the player develops his own winning plays, so the amusement is not lost in any play.

The soccer strategy game Futbolmate has a rectangular board in 108 green and yellow blocks; on these blocks are placed 18 round pieces in two colors to represent the two teams. The two goalkeepers move similar to the Queen in Chess – that is, as many spaces as desired in any straight direction. The other pieces can move only one diagonal space each turn. Another smaller round piece represents the ball. The objective of the game is to move all the pieces over the rectangular board to score the most goals in an established time. The game ends with a winner or a tie, similar to professional soccer.

The movement of the ball makes the difference. It does not follow a predetermined path, as its movement responds to the logic mazes of Ságaze, rules that allow the ball to rebound on the pieces and edges board, with players always trying to recover the ball or score a goal. Futbolmate uses no dice, no cards, and no other random elements – only the skill of the two players.

name: Gem Tactics
description:
Gem Tactics is a free to play Final Fantasy Tactics inspired board game. Players customize their army then use them to destroy their rivals. Players can discover many unique tactics, even after several games. The game can be played in 1-off skirmishes or in a larger campaign setting.

The first phase of play is the character creation team building. Players choose which classes they want to use. Some characters will have two classes. Each class has four skills; the player may unlock and use any one skill. An item shop adds further depth, as players have starting gold to spend on equipment and items for their characters.

The second phase of play is the battle on a grid map. Players take turns moving their units. The map may have desirable areas to move your units to, such as treasure or a tactical position. Some maps have campaign specific features like special victory conditions.
categories: Bluffing, Deduction, Dice, Fantasy, Fighting, Medieval, Miniatures, Party Game, Print & Play, Video Game Theme, Wargame
mechanics: Action Points, Area Majority / Influence, Campaign / Battle Card Driven, Commodity Speculation, Cooperative Game, Dice Rolling, Grid Movement, Hexagon Grid, Modular Board, Push Your Luck, Role Playing, Roll / Spin and Move, Storytelling

name: Great Art Close Up: The Detroit Institute of Arts
description:
From the publisher:
Discover art of the great museums of the world as you play 5 fun card games, including "Memory", "Old Maid", and 2 new matching games for children of different ages. Turn your next visit to the art museum into a treasure hunt with this deck of 48 cards masterpieces from the Detroit Institute of Arts. This game spans centuries of great art from old masters, such as Breughel and Bellini, to modern artists, such as Diego Rivera, Roy Lichtenstein, and Pablo Picasso.

Discover secret details in great works of art. Have fun pairing each full work of art with a close-up that shows every brushstroke.


The publication year has not been found but all other card games in this series were published in 2006.
categories: Card Game, Children's Game, Educational, Memory

name: Planet Hoarders
description:
A game of planetary collection!

The objective is to obtain the most planets/points in his or her collection by the time the deck runs out!

When planets are drawn they are immediately placed on the table. Using your probe cards on the planets themselves, you must either complete a sequence of three "like" probes over any number of turns or drop three dissimilar probes in a single turn to obtain that planet.

Use galactic catastrophes against your opponent such as meteor showers, solar flares or radiation!

Once the deck has run out, each player tallies up there points. 1 point for each planet + 1 additional point for each planet in similar systems (example: if you have two planets in the same system and another set of three in the same system, that's 5 additional points).

Quick and easy to play. Get the family in on it!

name: Scooby-Doo 2: Monsters Unleashed
description:
The object of the game is to be the first player to collect two monster tokens and the Control Panel card, then reach the control room.

On each player's turn they spin the spinner and advance the number of spaces as indicated by the arrow. If the player lands on one of several special spaces like a skull space, follow the directions. It could instruct the player to take the control panel card even if another player already has gotten it.

If the player lands on a corner space with a monster, both the monster and the player movers are put on a special race path and a "race" ensues by the use of the spinner. Another player spins for the monster. If you win the race, you collect the token that matches the monster.

After a player collects two monster tokens and the control panel card the player moves towards the control room. If the player reaches the control room without losing the control panel card, the player wins the game.
categories: Children's Game, Movies / TV / Radio theme

name: Eurexpert
description:
The goal is to become the first EUREXPERT answering knowledge questions on various European states.

The board represents Europe with its capitals, and color paths joining the big cities. Each country has five areas of knowledge: Art (literature, music, painting, cinema), Company (history, sports, science, institutions), Environment (geography, crafts and industry), Special (specialty, folklore, anecdotes), European Community (history, general, relations between states). Initially each player secretly sets its goal to answer 3 questions in five areas, or answer 6 questions in three areas, or answer 12 questions in one single domain.
Each player takes his departure from the capital.

In his turn player rolls the dice with colored faces and moves his pawn to space with this color. Player may answer the question in any space during the moving. If he answers correctly he may continue moving, if the answer is incorrect his turn is over.
When a player has reached his goal, he announces it and wins the game.

name: Dusk: Rise of the Occulites II
description:
Dusk - Rise of the Occulites II is the second game in the Rise of the Occulites Saga. The Occulite Tribes have expanded from their small groups of five, to much larger numbers. Over time individuals in these groups have evolved into specialist roles within their Tribe. Each Tribe pushes towards different objectives.

The game uses a Stratego-like fog of war to place your characters on a modular map. Each character has an ability which can only be utilised when it is revealed. The game also features the 'Natural Selection Deck' which first appeared in original game in the Saga: Dawn - Rise of the Occulites. You draw your hand of cards from the Natural Selection Deck during the game which you use to activate characters, move, fight, resolve events and activate special Tribal abilities.

Revealing your characters at the right time and using the 'Natural Selection Deck', your Tribe's abilities and the features of the map effectively will help you complete your objectives and win.

The composition of each Tribe is different and plays differently. The game offers a number of different Objectives of which between 1 and 3 are selected secretly before the game. The winner is the player who completes all his or her objectives first.
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Hand Management, Modular Board, Secret Unit Deployment

name: Bonus Circle
description:
This is a card based game where you roll the dice and travel around the game board collecting cards. The game board is made up of circles that you travel around. There is one center circle and four outer circles which are the bonus circles.

One player is assigned the broker and they hand out the cards and keep score as a player lands on certain spaces. The object is to collect all sets of listing cards - So if you collect all golf course cards (10 points each) - that is closed deal and the points assigned. (4 cards = 40 points)

The game is played to a total of 500. If no one reaches 500 the game starts over.

name: À vos marques
description:
Participants must guess a word whose playmaker defines as the number of letters.

After the time of an hourglass, if nobody finds the solution, the leader gives the first and last letter of the word. If the word is still not found, it gives the first and last two letters. The leader gets 10 points if no one comes to the solution.

A word found no letter is worth 10 points. A word with the first and last known letter 5 points, 1 point only if the two letters were extreme data.

The game starts with a 6 letter word, then the word is longer by a letter new handle up to 12 letters.

The winner is the player with the most points at the end of the game.


Each player wins the amount in the box. The next round begins by presenting the card after mixing in the boxes. After three rounds, the player who has scored the maximum gain wins.

name: Action Bourse
description: On each turn, a player draws a card and moves their pawn on the game board. The player can buy the square they land on from bank at the price specified, or can negotiate with an opponent if there is no more stock for sale. If a player doesn't have enough cash, they can borrow from the broker or sell some of their shares (5000F fine for negligence!). Buy low and sell high. The first player to 20 points wins.

name: No Hiding Place
description:
"A game of master detection with T.V.'s Scotland Yard Aces" - Based on the UK television series of the late 1950's.
2,3 or 4 players. Four attempts have been made on the life of a Government Official at his country house & there are 6 suspects - the object is to find the guilty man by collecting evidence cards. Players roll die & travel around the board. Evidence cards are collected from (1)visiting locations (2)other players (3) discards. These evidence cards combine to create suspects & weapons which are then revealed. There are various winning combinations

name: Action foot
description:
The aim of the game is to score the most goals in answering knowledge questions on the world of football.

The game board is a field with 22 players, 11 players of each team. The goal is to get the ball to player number 11, the only player to score a goal in!
The movement of the ball occurs from player to player depending on the outcome of the throw of a dice.

The player answer the question about World Cups, European Cups, National Football Regulations, Technic etc.
If the answer is correct, the player plays and traces its attack as he tries to reach his number 11 and get the goal to win the game.

name: Benjamin Blümchen: Fotowettbewerb
description:
Fotowettbewerb is a game for very young children, using licensed characters from Benjamin Blümchen, which is popular in Germany.
Benjamin is in the zoo, trying to take photos of four different animals (ten photos all in all) and stick them into his photo album. Unfortunately, the animals are shy, so they hide when the zookeeper is in their cage.
The kids take turns rolling a die. If it shows a color, they can move Benjamin to the cage of the animal in that color and take a picture token which fits into their album - but if the zookeeper is present, Benjamin gets no photos and just asks the zookeeper to move to the next cage. If they roll Benjamin, they can take a photo of any animal. The first player to fill his/her album is the winner.

name: Acrion Forêt
description:
This game allows you to discover the trees and animals of the Mediterranean forest, the play mechanism is similar to Mille Bornes.

The game consists 55 cards (trees, animals, dangers, protection) and 10 trees of various species. The goal is to create three "forest" composed of 3 tree-cards and 1 animal-card. Initially, each player receives 3 cards in each round of play, the player draws one card and either file a on the table or discards it. The card can be deposited to form a card tree forest, animal or card if they have been exposed at least one tree map, or a map last attack to hinder an opponent. The attack can be made against a tree map (fire, disease, waste paper) or animal card (hunter, roar in the forest). Some cards allow you to eliminate the hazard (natural park, treatment of diseases ...). Card "Garbage" forces the player to skip his turn (time to clean ...) card "disease" can destroy multiple cards if it is not removed quickly, even for the card "Fire" (canceled by "Fire" or "Clearing").

When a player has 3 tree-cards and 1 Animal-card during his turn he receives a small wooden tree as a forest. The winner is the player who has 3 forest.

name: Memory Challenge: New York Edition
description:
Publisher Blurb:

Now you can experience the world’s most popular matching game with all the sites and sounds of the Big Apple. Our nation’s most populous city is home to some of the world’s most recognized sites and attractions. Inside this booklet you’ll learn more about the City’s iconic buildings, bridges, monuments, and venues while also learning about the new game play features that make the New York City Edition of Memory more challenging and fun! Tourist guide cards add strategy and interaction among the players by adding extra turns and steal matches. Turn the page and let the adventure begin!

name: Ulewin
description:
Football related card game. Two decks of cards are provided. One is used for a Match number and the other is used for generating the results of the matches.

This is an incredibly basic game considering the expense of producing a game with 127 cards in total. Each player is dealt an even number of Match cards.
