Concurrent is a tabletop adaptation of the PC game, Risk 2, which is a computer adaptation of the classic board game, Risk.

Instead of the standard turn-taking that occurs in Risk, Concurrent utilizes a system where the players determine their troop deployment and attacks simultaneously.

The game consists of a game board, representing various countries and territories across the Earth, with connections between the countries by borders and some lines across continents and to island countries/territories. In addition, there are cards which have the various countries/territories listed on the card, and plastic figures which represent the player's army.

At the beginning of the game, all cards are passed out to the players, which represents the starting countries for each player. Afterward, the players are allowed a certain number of army units, relative to the total number of players, which they are allow to place on their starting countries.

At the beginning of each round, players are given a piece of paper to write all their actions on. Included is new unit deployment (based on total countries controlled, largest connected empire, continents controlled, and any matching card set the player can turn in), attacks, and the player's surge attack. Players may attack any country using army units they control on adjacent countries, but must leave at least one unit in their country as a defender. In addition, players may elect to make one surge attack, where if one of their attacks is successful, after all other attacks are resolved, they may make one more attack to attempt to conquer another country.

Once all players have completed their decisions for the round, they reveal said decisions, deploy new units, and announce all attacks. If there are any border clashes (two countries trying to attack each other), they are resolved first. Battles are resolved using custom 12-sided dice. There are multiple dice that are rolled relative to the army size. Each die is numbered 1-6, but the distribution of numbers changes relative to the army size (eg. the larger the army, the more likely the die is to roll higher numbers). Each player rolls the die, with the player rolling the lowest number losing a number of units relative to the smallest army (the larger the army, the more units lost per roll). In the event of a tie on the die roll, both players reroll. The battle is over once one attacking army in the border clash is eliminated.

After border clashes are resolved, mass invasions are resolved. Mass invasions occur when multiple countries attack the same country. This can be multiple armies from one player, or more than one. Mass invasions are resolved the same as border clashes, the only difference being that, unlike border clashes where there is not a specific attacker, the attacking player wins ties. Just like border clashes, the player who loses the roll also loses units relative to the smallest army size in the battle. The mass invasion is completed when one of the armies is eliminated.

Invasions are then resolved, which are the same as mass invasions, but are only from one country to another. After invasions are resolved, spoils of war are resolved. Spoils of war occur when two or more players attack the same country in a mass invasion and multiple attacking armies remain. Spoils of war are resolved like border clashes, where ties are resolved with a reroll.

After all attacks are resolved, players will resolve the surge attack they noted on their paper. Surge attacks are resolved like invasions, or mass invasions if multiple players surge into country. In the event of a successful mass invasion surge attack, the players resolve the conquest with a spoils of war.

Each round occurs the same as listed above, until one player finishes the round with a previously agreed upon control limit (60% control of countries, 80%, etc). That player is the winner of Concurrent!
mechanics: Area Majority / Influence, Dice Rolling, Set Collection

name: Fire and Flora
description:
A casual, resource-management game about nature, beauty, and connections.

This is an unusual game because it is dual-purpose. Firstly, and most importantly, it is a good game: fun and interesting, and especially so when played with friends. However, at the same time, it is also designed to share and promote understanding and appreciation of nature.

The game is centered around plant cards. Every plant card has a point value, and the winner of the game is the first player to collect 10 points. Plant Cards grow and change in response to randomly drawn Event Cards, and player-used Resource Cards. There are thirteen different species of plant in this game, and each has its own personality, which means that each responds to Events and Resources in different ways.

To be successful, you must collect, trade, and play Resources in order to improve the plants on your own landscape, foil your opponents' plans, protect yourself from dangerous Events, and defend yourself from the snarkiness of your opponents.

name: Wordner
description:
A party-style card game where players use their creativity to finish prompts by building off of starter words. These are judged by another player who selects his/her favorite. The player who submitted this is then awarded a point.

The game begins with one player being chosen as the judge. A blue prompt card and an orange starter card are pulled from the deck and read out loud to everyone.

The remaining players finish the prompt by writing a phrase that incorporates at least one of the starter words. These phrases are known as wordners, and may make starter words plural, change their tense, and add other words to them.

The players submit their wordners on a piece of paper to the player on the judge's left, who reads them out loud. The judge selects his/her favorite, and the creator of this is awarded a point represented by the round's blue card.

Now, the player to the judge's left becomes the judge and a new round begins. The first player to collect 5 blue cards wins!
categories: Card Game, Humor, Party Game, Print & Play

name: Reservoir Dogs
description:
"Reservoir Dogs" The board game

Six professional criminals are hired by Joe Cabot and his son Nice Guy Eddie for a job. Not know each other and remain anonymous, hidden under color names: Mr. Orange, Mr. White, Mr. Pink, Mr. Blonde, Mr. Brown and Mr. Blue. Prepare thoroughly robbery diamond store, but police shows up unexpectedly at the time of making a slaughter robbery resulting in the deaths of several police officers, and employees. All suspect that there is a traitor infiltrated in the group.

Thieves who manage to survive and get to the warehouse with the diamonds will win the game, but there is an undercover agent who will try to sabotage them. Police will also further complicated the getaway. Besides the briefcase with diamonds can change hands and perhaps one of the robbers take not to share with others
categories: Bluffing, Deduction, Movies / TV / Radio theme
mechanics: Hand Management, Modular Board, Role Playing, Roll / Spin and Move, Secret Unit Deployment, Voting

name: Stavropol Bashni
description:
Stavropol Bashni is a stacking game from the Checkers family. It features shared pieces. As in all Checkers games, the aim of the game is to leave the opponent without a legal move. It is played on a traditional 8x8 Checkers board with stones that are suitable for Bashni, i.e. stackable and with kings being turned men or pieces of a different color, as most traditional Russian sets are.

The rules follow Bashni. In short, when a man or king is captured, it is not taken from the board, but put under the piece which captures the men. This way, stacks are formed. Generally, to topmost of piece of a stack decides which player the stack belongs to, how the stack moves, it is the piece that is promoted on reaching a back rank, and it is the piece that is captured. If the topmost piece of a stack is captured and the next piece at the top belongs to the opponent, the stack switches allegiance and belongs to the opponent then.

The difference to Bashni is that pieyes are shared - as in Stavropol Checkers. A player may move stacks owned by the opponent, too, according to the rules for the topmost piece. The exact winning condition is therefor: a player loses when it is his turn and the stacks belonging to him have no legal move.

Online play:

igGameCenter

name: 2 in 1
description:
This two player game is packed in an small box and offers two variants.
1. Each player has four pawns which are placed in the corners of the board, specifically the corners that present one field (dot). The object of the game is to reach the corner of the opponent with all four pawns (like Halma). Jumping pawns, both own and adversary's, is allowed.
2. The second is an Asalto-like game. One of the players has only one pawn, the other four, The object of the game is to encircle the one pawn. The four pawn player may move his pawns only in de forward direction. The one pawn player can move each desired direction, Jumping is not allowed.

name: Shinobi: The Ninja Training Game
description:
The land of Nippon is riven by civil war and the leaders of the different factions have a number of secret missions they need carried out. As master of one of the four great Ninja clans you must train your warriors so they are ready to carry out the missions offered. But beware, if you take too long one of your rival clans may undertake a mission before you and steal the rich reward offered for carrying it out.

In Shinobi: Way of the Ninja, you control a ninja clan and must perform different missions in order to obtain wealth and win the game. The missions you are called on to carry out are represented by three Mission cards that will tell you what you need to do (the task), where the mission is to be carried out (the location), and what problems may arise that will hinder you in the missions execution (complications). Each of these things requires one or more Skill cards from your hand to overcome. For example, if the mission required the use of unarmed combat you would need to play that Skill card in order to carry it out.

Once you have collected all of the Skill cards you need you may carry out a mission and reap the rewards for your clan. Unfortunately you will rarely have the right cards in your hand to perform a mission straight away. Instead you will need to store cards from your hand for future use by placing cards face-down from your hand into one of two dojos you control. Storing cards in this way represents you training the ninjas in your clan to perform a mission.

Keeping track of the cards placed in each dojo is challenging as you are not normally allowed to examine the cards once they are placed. You must use your powers of concentration and memory to remember which cards you have placed so that you can use them when you are ready to carry out a mission. Although this is difficult at first, you will find that your mental abilities quickly sharpen and that you will become increasingly skilled at the game. This is as it should be: being the master of a ninja clan requires great mental fortitude, and Shinobi: Way of the Ninja will test it to the utmost. However, if you get completely stuck, you can always visit the sensei who will (at a cost) allow you to examine the cards you have placed.

You receive a reward for completing each mission in the form of gold. The harder a mission the more gold you will receive, but the more cards you will need to play to carry the mission out. At the end of the game the player who has amassed the largest fortune wins.

name: Splattering Egg Toss Game
description:
A dexterity game in which two players are each equipped with a small plastic frying pan and a squishy plastic "egg". The opponents simultaneously toss their egg to the other person, who attempts to catch it in their frying pan. This repeats until someone drops their egg and loses.

There is also a solo version in which one person sees how many times they can toss the egg up in the air and catch it.

name: Time: A Game of Chance for Many Players
description:
The time theme is very loosely pasted onto this game. The clocks used on the board and the cards could have just as easily been card denominations. This is a simple game of match.

A dealer/banker is assigned. Each player is dealt five cards face up. The dealer then deals one card face down on each of the 12 clocks on the board. In the first round of play the dealer turns up one of the twelve cards at a time. If a player has a matching card in one of his/her upturned five, then the player has to pay in the amount of chips/points indicated at that point on the board in large red letters. If the player has two matching cards, the player must pay double and so on. If the overturned card matches the time on the board at that spot, TIME is called and all payments are doubled. In this round all payments are made to the pot. After all twelve cards are overturned they are returned to the deck, reshuffled, and a fresh twelve are distributed to the twelve clock positions face down. The players keep their original five cards.

In the second round, as each of the twelve cards are overturned, payments are made to the players following the same rules as in round one. The rules do not explain the end of the game scenario. Nor do they explain if the rounds continue to alternate put/take. It is also unclear how many chips the players start with. It is suggested that the white chips equal 1, the yellow chips 2, the red chips 5 and the blue chips 10.

name: Seifenkistenrennen
description:
A simple racing game for two players. Movement is determined by a six-sided die.

The game consists of a board (showing a 37-space racing track), 4 player tokens and a die. Both players try to get their soapbox derby racer (i.e. one of their two player tokens) to the finish line first. Players take turns rolling the die. The player's first token (the racer) is moved according to the result of the die roll. If the racer lands on a stop space, the player has to send his/her mechanic (= the second token) the following turns. Only when the mechanic has reached the racer, the racer can move on. The mechanic stays on the stop space until the racer lands on another stop space.

The player whose racer reaches the finish line first wins the game.

name: Skizirkus
description:
An educational game aimed at teaching the rules of conduct on ski pistes ("Pistenregeln").

The game combines roll-and-move elements with trivia game elements. The board shows four different skiing areas. Players move their player tokens up the ski lift according to their die roll results. Once they've reached the top, they can ski downhill (again using die roll results), but first they have to answer a question connected with skiing, such as "What is forbidden on a chair lift?", "What is important when overtaking other skiers?" etc. Apart from questions on the rules of conduct, there are general skiing trivia questions like "Where was skiing invented?" or "When did the first skiing race in Central Europe take place?"
The first player to complete four downhill races wins the game.

name: La boîte à questions WWE
description:
Similar to La Boîte à Quiz.

Questions about WWE and wrestling.

The Box provides seventy-eight quizzes. Each card contains a fact and number of questions on a common theme.
Answer correctly and score a point. The player with the most points wins.

name: La boîte à questions Asterix
description:
Similar to La Boîte à Quiz.

Questions about Asterix.

The Box provides seventy-eight quizzes. Each card contains a fact and number of questions on a common theme.
Answer correctly and score a point. The player with the most points wins.
categories: Card Game, Comic Book / Strip, Trivia

name: La Boîte à questions insolites
description:
Similar to La Boîte à Quiz.

Topics are nations and customs, words and phrases, inventions and discoveries, history and geography etc. A thick booklet contains extensive responses.

The Box provides seventy-eight quizzes. Each card contains a fact and number of questions on a common theme.
Answer correctly and score a point. The player with the most points wins.

name: La boîte à Quiz junior
description:
Based on the La Boîte à Quiz the game is more suitable for young audiences. The box contains everything needed to play except an hourglass, paper and pencil.

Topics are animals, plants, the earth, the human body, space, history and science. Each card contains a fact and number of questions on a common theme. Answer correctly and score a point. The player with the most points wins.
categories: Animals, Card Game, Children's Game, Trivia

name: La boîte à questions
description:
Similar to La Boîte à Quiz with 150 general knowledge questions.

The Box provides seventy-eight quizzes. Each card contains a fact and number of questions on a common theme.
Answer correctly and score a point. The player with the most points wins.

name: Landmaus & Stadtmaus: Sherlock Maus
description:
A roll-and-move game based on the cartoon series "The Country Mouse and the City Mouse Adventures".
The aim of this cooperative children's game is to lead all 4 pawns through the story of the stolen diamond and to solve the case together with Emily, Alexander and Sherlock Mouse before Notail Nogoodnik, the thief, is seen five times.

The board shows a track consisting of lots of coloured spaces and pictures from the cartoon series. There are four pawns. Players take turns rolling the colour die. The active player moves a pawn of his/her choice to the next space of the colour on the die roll (all players can move all pawns). If a pawn lands on a yellow space, one of the twenty, randomly distributed face-down tiles has to be turned over. If it shows a picture from the board, the pawn is moved to the corresponding space. If the tile shows Notail Nogoodnik, it stays face-up and the player's turn is over.
To get a pawn to the finish line, the spaces has to be reached exactly.

If all four player pawns reach the finish line, all players win together. If five tiles showing Notail Nogoodnik are turned over, they all lose together.
categories: Children's Game, Movies / TV / Radio theme, Racing
mechanics: Cooperative Game, Roll / Spin and Move

name: ScrapIron
description:
A post-apocalyptic vehicular combat game for 2 to 8 players. It uses the quick setup and rapid play of a card game and combines it with the tactile and visual strategy and excitement of a miniatures game. Nothing needs to be written down during play, it's a great way to introduce younger card game players to the world of miniature gaming. Gameplay is normally 15-30 minutes and most players will understand the rules after their first game. How many wargames can fit all their rules on a single sheet of paper?

ScrapIron is 100% Zombie Free!

Players each use a miniature vehicle as their playing piece. The game was designed around the popular Hot Wheels and Matchbox lines but can be easily adapted to any size vehicle.

Players choose equipment from an Equipment Deck prior to the start of the game.

Action cards are chosen during the planning phase and placed face down. Order if play is determined randomly and actions are then carried out in that order.

When damage is dealt, cards of the Damage Deck are given to the target player. Damage cards will either assign Structural Damage to the vehicle, 10 points and the car is out of the game, or cause special effects. These effects could cause the car to spin out and face a random direction, cause the player to lose Action cards or otherwise harm the target.

When the last car remains that player is the winner! That did not take long, why not play again?

name: Blarney: The Definitive Word Game
description:
This game consists of decks of cards each with five words and their definitions on them. The Blarney Master - chosen by the roll of the die - selects a card, then chooses one of the words by speaking it. The 3-minute timer is begun and the players have that long to write down their definition of the word.

Scoring is determined the players voting for the "best definition" and points are awarded to the player with the most votes and the player with the best definition and the Blarney Master if no one votes for the correct definition. The one with the most points gets a green Blarney stone to indicate such. That ends a round; then the Blarney Master position passes to the next player.

On certain cards, one of the words has no meaning so is simply "Blarney" and the Master must make up a plausible definition.

The game ends after 10 rounds; the winner being the player with the most Blarney stones.

name: Animals
description:
Animals contains 70 cards for three different level games.

• In Pets of King, each of Kings in the forest has his/her beloved pets. When these animals appear in the forest, take the chance and stay them. But, other Kings may also have same interest or unfavorable animals may also be captured. This game tests response and actions to catch different Animals cards.

• In Forest Olympic, animals in the forest join the Olympic game. Help them to win and the most effective team will seek love from animals. Players have to form Animals team to compete each round and be the first one to play all cards from his/her hand.

• In Rescue the Animals, there is a big fire in the forest! Help rescue animals to life boats. The more the Animals a player save, the more is the point the chance to win he/she gets. However, players have to be think carefully how to arrange Animals in their only life boat.

name: Woof and me
description:
Woof and Me is a super-fun educational board game about pet care and responsibility.
Be the player with the most bones at finish to win the game. The winner gets to choose another dog from the Animal Shelter.
Educational Value: basic fundamentals of number recognition, encourages the ability to count, simple money exchange, problems that have solutions, social interaction and being a responsible pet owner.
Includes game board, directions with picture book, 6 dog game pieces, Doggy Dollars, 130 brown bone cards, 8 spay/neuter cards, 6 license cards, 14 problem/solution cards, 2 dice

PRODUCT DESCRIPTION: Woof and Me is a wonderfully fun educational board game to help children value and respect our animal friends. Woof and Me game teaches children awareness in pet care responsibility. Use your cute doggy game piece to follow the game path and collect cards which show different dog breeds receiving essentials like water, food, health care, etc. The player with the most cards at finish wins. Easy to learn and super fun to play. EDUCATIONAL VALUE: Woof and Me Board Game socially involves children through interaction. Children have fun while learning pet care and responsibility. By counting out loud, your child will quickly grasp the basic fundamentals of number recognition and encourage the ability to count. Doggy Dollars help the youngest of players understand simple money exchange. Woof and Me introduces problems that pets can face and solutions to those problems. Social skills, like communicating verbally and enjoying conversation with others, all help develop a child’s communication skills. Whether you are preparing to get a puppy or a grown dog, it is important for children to learn how to be a responsible pet owner. Your dog will rely on you for its entire life! Ages 5 and up. 2 to 5 players

This colorful visual educational game has received numerous positive testimonials from after school programs in the Phoenix Arizona metropolitan area.

name: Challenge & Reply
description:
Tabletop miniatures naval wargame, designed for small scale (1:3000 or smaller) miniatures. 1 mini=1 ship, rules are designed for large actions, and are relatively simple, allowing for fairly simple bookkeeping (6+ ships per A4/letter sheet easily). Considerable detail is still preserved, such as ships carrying multiple size classes of guns per arc (ahead, broadside & aft), differing effects of boiler hits due to fuel type, etc. Submarine & aircraft actions are included, as are formations and campaign tracking.

Naval lists are included for Royal Navy & Kriegsmarine. Layout & typeface are rather old-fashioned in appearance.
categories: Miniatures, Nautical, Wargame, World War I
